title: 2004 French Open
text:
The 2004 French Open was the 108th edition of the tournament. <a href="Gast%C3%B3n%20Gaudio">Gastón Gaudio</a> became the first men's <a href="Open%20Era">Open Era</a> Grand Slam title winner to save two match points in the final; the last time that had happened was 70 years earlier. Gaudio also became the first <a href="Argentina">Argentine</a> man since <a href="Guillermo%20Vilas">Guillermo Vilas</a> to win a <a href="Grand%20Slam%20%28tennis%29">grand slam</a>, in 1979. Fellow Argentine <a href="Guillermo%20Coria">Guillermo Coria</a>, widely regarded as the favourite and best <a href="clay%20court">clay court</a> player in the world coming into the tournament, was seeded 3rd for the event, whereas Gaudio was unseeded (ranked 44th) and with only two titles to his name, both of which he had won over two years before. After winning the first two sets convincingly, Coria began suffering from leg <a href="cramp">cramp</a>s. Gaudio won the next two sets; however, Coria came back and was up two breaks of serve in the final set. Coria had two match points at 6–5 before Gaudio prevailed 0–6, 3–6, 6–4, 6–1, 8–6. Gaudio also became the first man to win a Grand Slam tournament final after being <a href="bagel%20%28tennis%29">bagelled</a> in the first set. The tournament was noted for the excellent performance of the Argentine players – in addition to the two finalists, there were a semifinalist (<a href="David%20Nalbandian">David Nalbandian</a>) and a quarterfinalist (<a href="Juan%20Ignacio%20Chela">Juan Ignacio Chela</a>). It was also highlighted by a first round match between <a href="Fabrice%20Santoro">Fabrice Santoro</a> and <a href="Arnaud%20Cl%C3%A9ment">Arnaud Clément</a>, lasting 6 hours and 33 minutes and ending in Clement's defeat 6–4, 6–3, 6–7, 3–6, 16–14, setting a new record for the longest singles match in the <a href="History%20of%20tennis%23Open%20era">open era</a>, which would stand until <a href="Isner%26amp%3Bndash%3BMahut%20match%20at%20the%202010%20Wimbledon%20Championships">Wimbledon 2010</a>. It was also the last Grand Slam tournament to feature neither <a href="Roger%20Federer">Roger Federer</a> nor <a href="Rafael%20Nadal">Rafael Nadal</a> in the semi-finals until the <a href="2012%20US%20Open%20%28tennis%29">2012 US Open</a>.
In the women's draw, <a href="Anastasia%20Myskina">Anastasia Myskina</a> became first Russian female tennis player to win a Grand Slam title. The next two Grand Slams were also won by Russian women (<a href="Maria%20Sharapova">Maria Sharapova</a> at <a href="2004%20Wimbledon%20Championships">Wimbledon</a> and <a href="Svetlana%20Kuznetsova">Svetlana Kuznetsova</a> at the <a href="2004%20US%20Open%20%28tennis%29">US Open</a>). She also became the first French Open women's title winner after having saved a match point en route to the title (against Svetlana Kuznetsova in the 4th round).
In the mixed doubles, French players <a href="Tatiana%20Golovin">Tatiana Golovin</a> and <a href="Richard%20Gasquet">Richard Gasquet</a> (aged 16 and 17 respectively) won the tournament after entering as <a href="Wild%20card%20%28sports%29">wildcard</a>s. France also saw success in the boys' singles, where <a href="Ga%C3%ABl%20Monfils">Gaël Monfils</a> won.
<a href="Juan%20Carlos%20Ferrero">Juan Carlos Ferrero</a> and <a href="Justine%20Henin">Justine Henin-Hardenne</a> were both unsuccessful in defending their 2003 titles; both being eliminated in the second round. It would be the last time until the <a href="2009%20French%20Open">2009 French Open</a> that both defending champions were defeated in the same round. In Henin's case, her early exit would be the last time a top seed lost within the first two rounds of any Grand Slam until <a href="Ana%20Ivanovic">Ana Ivanovic</a> lost in the second round of the <a href="2008%20US%20Open%20%28tennis%29">2008 US Open</a>. Henin's loss to <a href="Tathiana%20Garbin">Tathiana Garbin</a> in the second round was her only defeat at the tournament between <a href="2003%20French%20Open">2003</a> and <a href="2009%20French%20Open">2009</a> (she did not play in 2008 and 2009).
This was the last Grand Slam where two first time singles players (both men's and women's) won in the first major titles.
